sub_topic: Calculation of latent heat of vaporization of a substance
message_1: What is the latent heat of vaporization of water at room temperature and standard pressure given that it has a heat of vaporization of 40.67 kJ/mol and a boiling point of 100℃?
message_2:
The latent heat of vaporization of water at room temperature and standard pressure can be calculated using the given heat of vaporization (40.67 kJ/mol) and the molar mass of water (18.015 g/mol). The latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat required to convert 1 gram of a substance from the liquid phase to the gaseous phase at a constant temperature and pressure.

Latent heat of vaporization (L) = Heat of vaporization / Molar mass of water

L = 40.67 kJ/mol / 18.015 g/mol

To convert kJ/mol to J/g, we need to multiply by 1000:

L = (40.67 * 1000) J/mol / 18.015 g/mol

L ≈ 2260 J/g

So, the latent heat of vaporization of water at room temperature and standard pressure is approximately 2260 J/g. Note that this value is an approximation, as the latent heat of vaporization can vary slightly depending on the specific temperature and pressure conditions.
